title: How to Clean an Electric Guitar

steps.headline: Start by taking off the strings.
steps.description: You need to remove all of them, no matter what is said about string tension. Do it by any means but don't destroy your guitar.

steps.headline: Gather your tools.
steps.description: Once all the strings are off, get a microfiber towel (preferably) or a non-lint rag, regular, plain ol' tap water, fine steel wool, sandpaper, a set of screwdrivers, pliers, and tape (only use painter's tape or automotive tape).

steps.headline: Start with the neck or body.
steps.description: It doesn't matter, but in this tutorial we will start with the neck.

steps.headline: Make sure all tuning pegs are snug but not tight.
steps.description: Use the screwdrivers and the pliers to snug up all screws and the nut and washers on the peg.

steps.headline: Dip a small portion of the towel into the water.
steps.description: Wipe the neck down, scrubbing inside the frets. You don't need to water a dead tree, get off all excess water, and do not ever use oils or other guitar "care" products.

steps.headline: Wipe down the body, limiting the water used.
steps.description: Tighten all screws and watch you don't mess with your set up. Do not use any guitar "care" products.

steps.headline: Spray contact cleaner in your switches and pots.
steps.description: They will become dirty and have a terrible sound to them.

steps.headline: Clean the frets, if you want.
steps.description: This part is time consuming, so you may skip it if you like. Tape off the frets, and use the steel wool to clean each and every fret. Remember that the steel wool will scratch your fretboard, so tape off right at the fret.

steps.headline: Once your guitar is clean, restring it and play.

Once all the strings are off, get a microfiber towel (preferably) or a non-lint rag, regular, plain ol' tap water, fine steel wool, sandpaper, a set of screwdrivers, pliers, and tape (only use painter's tape or automotive tape). Start with the neck or body. It doesn't matter, but in this tutorial we will start with the neck. Make sure all tuning pegs are snug but not tight. Use the screwdrivers and the pliers to snug up all screws and the nut and washers on the peg. Dip a small portion of the towel into the water. Wipe the neck down, scrubbing inside the frets. You don't need to water a dead tree, get off all excess water, and do not ever use oils or other guitar "care" products. Wipe down the body, limiting the water used. Tighten all screws and watch you don't mess with your set up. Do not use any guitar "care" products. Spray contact cleaner in your switches and pots. They will become dirty and have a terrible sound to them. Clean the frets, if you want. This part is time consuming, so you may skip it if you like. Tape off the frets, and use the steel wool to clean each and every fret. Remember that the steel wool will scratch your fretboard, so tape off right at the fret. Once your guitar is clean, restring it and play.
